byline.contributor: Charlie Savage reported from Washington, and Aida Alami from Paris.
byline.original: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and AIDA ALAMI

abstract: Moroccan government is holding Younis Shokuri, citizen released from Guantanamo Bay prison, in indefinite custody and is considering criminal charges against him, despite its promises to release Shokuri soon after his repatriation; situation points to difficulty of emptying Guantanamo and of finding places to send detainees that will watch them without violating their rights.
lead_paragraph: Younis Shokuri feared being repatriated to Morocco, and his lawyers said they were assured there was a deal between the U.S. and Moroccan governments. Yet he remains in custody in his native country.

headline.main: Guantánamo Prisoner Sent Home to Morocco Remains in Legal Limbo
headline.print_headline: Released From Guantánamo, but in Legal Limbo in Morocco

snippet: Younis Shokuri feared being repatriated to Morocco, and his lawyers said they were assured there was a deal between the U.S. and Moroccan governments. Yet he remains in custody in his native country.
